Welcome to ENIGMA’s documentation!

src.data_processing module

class src.data_processing.processors.Preprocessor.Preprocessor(processor_name: str = None, path_to_data: str = None, path_to_processed_data: str = None, path_to_save: str = None, features: List[str] = None, target: str = None, X_train: DataFrame = None, X_test: DataFrame = None, y_train: Series = None, y_test: Series = None)

Bases: object

Summary

Preprocessor is responsible for loading, preprocessing, and saving processed the data. for model building and experimentation

processor_name

The name of the processor.

Type:

str or None

path_to_datastr or None

The path to the raw data file.

path_to_processed_datastr or None

The path to the processed data file.

featuresList[str] or None

A list of column names that correspond to the features in the dataset.

targetstr or None

The name of the target variable in the dataset.

X_trainpd.DataFrame or None

The training features data.

X_testpd.DataFrame or None

The test features data.

y_trainpd.Series or None

The training target data.

y_testpd.Series or None

The test target data.

load_data()

loads data from path_to_data or path_to_processed_data into data attribute. If both attributes are not None, both are loaded.

one_hot_encode()

encodes the data using one hot encoding.

split_train_test()

splits data into train and test sets using train_test_split from sklearn.model_selection

split_train_by_query()

spilts data into train and test sets based on a specified column’s cutoff value.

save_processed_data()

saves processed data attribute to path_to_processed_data

load_processed_data()

class method that loads an instance of Preprocessor from a pickle file.

load_data(load_processed_data: str = False) → Type[Preprocessor]

# Summary loads data from path_to_data into data attribute. first checks that filetype is parquet (currently only supported filetype)

# attributes stores data from path_to_data into data attribute as a Pd.DataFrame object.

Returns:

self

classmethod load_processor(file_path)

load a saved processor object from a pickle file

Parameters:

file_path (str) – the path to the pickle file containing the saved processor object

one_hot_encode(labels: List[str], data: DataFrame = None)

# Summary

## Args:

  • df (pd.DataFrame, optional): dataframe . Defaults to self.data.

  • labels (list, optional): list of column names to one hot encode, these columns are prefixed to the name, and original columns are dropped.

## Attributes: - processed_data: pd.DataFrame this is the processed encoded data that joined with the original data- ready for model input - labels: list of column names to one hot encode, these columns are prefixed to the name, and original columns are dropped. :returns: self

save_datasets_to_parquet(path=None, save_downsampled=False)

save_processor(path_to_save_processor=None)

Summary

Saves the processed data to a file.

param path:

type path:

str path to save the processed data to.

param Notes:

param ——:

param The method creates a new directory called processors in the same directory as:

param the processed data:

param if it doesn’t exist already. It then saves the processor object:

param to a pickle file with the same name as the processor:

<processed_data_directory>/processors/<processor_name>.pkl

param using the following format:

<processed_data_directory>/processors/<processor_name>.pkl

param Returns:

None

save_processor_to_h5()

self.filename = os.path.join(self.path_to_save_processor, f’{self.processor_name}.h5’) with h5py.File(self.filename, ‘w’) as file:

instance_group = file.create_group(‘instance’)

for attr_name, attr_value in vars(self).items():
if isinstance(attr_value, pd.DataFrame):

# Save DataFrame as a separate group df_group = instance_group.create_group(attr_name) for col_name, col_data in attr_value.items():

df_group.create_dataset(col_name, data=col_data)

elif isinstance(attr_value, (int, float, str)):

instance_group.create_dataset(attr_name, data=attr_value)

else:

# Convert non-compatible types to string representation instance_group.create_dataset(attr_name, data=str(attr_value))

split_train_by_query(column_name, cutoff, processed_data=False, data=None)

Summary

Split the processed data into training and testing sets based on a specified column’s cutoff value.

param column_name:

Name of the column to split the data on.

type column_name:

str

param cutoff:

The cutoff value to use to split the data. Any value less than or equal to the cutoff will be in the training set, while any value greater than the cutoff will be in the testing set.

type cutoff:

float

returns:

  • None

  • Notes

  • —— – Updates the class instance with four attributes - X_train, X_test, y_train, and y_test. X_train and y_train are the training features and target data, respectively, which consist of rows from the processed data where the value of the specified column is less than or equal to the cutoff. X_test and y_test are the testing features and target data, respectively, which consist of rows from the processed data where the value of the specified column is greater than the cutoff.

split_train_test(test_size=0.2, random_state=42, processed_data=False, data=None)

Summary

Split the processed data into training and testing sets using the train_test_split method from scikit-learn.

param - test_size (float:

Defaults to 0.2 (i.e., 20% of the data is used for testing).

type - test_size (float:

the proportion of the data to use for testing, should be between 0 and 1.

param optional):

Defaults to 0.2 (i.e., 20% of the data is used for testing).

type optional):

the proportion of the data to use for testing, should be between 0 and 1.

param - random_state (int:

Defaults to 42, which means that the same random seed will be used every time the method is called, ensuring reproducibility of the results.

type - random_state (int:

controls the randomness of the data splitting process.

param optional):

Defaults to 42, which means that the same random seed will be used every time the method is called, ensuring reproducibility of the results.

type optional):

controls the randomness of the data splitting process.

param Returns:

param ——-:

param - self:

X_train and y_train are the training features and target data, while X_test and y_test are the testing features and target data.

type - self:

the class instance with attributes X_train, X_test, y_train, and y_test.
